Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Random Dynamics on Networks
Award.AbstractNarration:
Transport and distribution networks come in a number of forms, from animal cardiovascular and respiratory systems to communication and industrial infrastructures. Practical issues abound: prediction of local spikes, estimation of perfusion, and impact of structural changes such as vessel occlusion. The complexity of such phenomena can be illustrated by the well-known Braess' paradox: adding links to a transportation network might not improve the operation of the system! In spite of recent successes, our understanding of network flows is usually limited to small deterministic problems, while most applications correspond to large uncertain ones. The goal of this project is to enable improved predictions in biological and technological transport and diffusion networks. For instance, can one predict how cerebral blood flow will be affected if one of the carotids becomes narrow or blocked? Will the vasculature allow for re-routing? If so, with what probability and how fast?

The main challenge in this research project is the presence of uncertainties. For many applications, only partial information about the systems is available. For instance the size or even the presence of a specific vessel might be uncertain or the status of a router unknown. The analysis of such problems requires the creation of novel mathematical tools and numerical methods to describe how uncertainties propagate through vast and complex networks. The computational tools to be constructed will provide information, usually probabilistic in nature, regarding phenomena that are difficult, expensive, or impossible to measure.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project deals with development and systematic analysis of a new probabilistic framework to quantify the impact of parametric uncertainties on model predictions. Rather than relying on computationally expensive Monte Carlo simulations, in which thousands of deterministic problems have to be solved, our method aims to derive and solve one deterministic equation for the probability density function (PDF) or cumulative distribution function (CDF) of quantities of interest. This allows one to assess the probability of rare events and to provide error bars (confidence intervals) for model predictions. The project has resulted in fourteen publications in the leading peer-reviewed journals in several fields of science and engineering. Specifically,
* We have developed a method of distributions, which comprises PDF (probability density function) and CDF (cumulative  as a robust and computationally efficient tool for uncertainty quantification in hyperbolic systems with high stochastic dimensions.
* We have extended this method to parabolic (advection-diffusion) equations and explored the viability of nonlocal formulations of the PDF and CDF equations. 
* We have developed mathematical methods to study propagation of noise from a fine (e.g., discrete) scale to a coarse (e.g., continuum) scale, and its effects on the accuracy and robustness of numerical algorithms;
* We have applied these other uncertainty quantification techniques developed in the course of this project to  biomedical research dealing with microcirculation and cell biology.
In summary, the results achieved in this project enhance the reliability of science-based predictions of the behavior of multiscale multi-physics systems.

Last Modified: 12/04/2018
Modified by: Daniel M Tartakovsky
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The project deals with development and systematic analysis of a new probabilistic framework to quantify the impact of parametric uncertainties on model predictions. Rather than relying on computationally expensive Monte Carlo simulations, in which thousands of deterministic problems have to be solved, our method aims to derive and solve one deterministic equation for the probability density function (PDF) or cumulative distribution function (CDF) of quantities of interest. This allows one to assess the probability of rare events and to provide error bars (confidence intervals) for model predictions. The project has resulted in fourteen publications in the leading peer-reviewed journals in several fields of science and engineering. Specifically, * We have developed a method of distributions, which comprises PDF (probability density function) and CDF (cumulative as a robust and computationally efficient tool for uncertainty quantification in hyperbolic systems with high stochastic dimensions. * We have extended this method to parabolic (advection-diffusion) equations and explored the viability of nonlocal formulations of the PDF and CDF equations. * We have developed mathematical methods to study propagation of noise from a fine (e.g., discrete) scale to a coarse (e.g., continuum) scale, and its effects on the accuracy and robustness of numerical algorithms; * We have applied these other uncertainty quantification techniques developed in the course of this project to biomedical research dealing with microcirculation and cell biology. In summary, the results achieved in this project enhance the reliability of science-based predictions of the behavior of multiscale multi-physics systems.
